author: bergmeister
body:
If you launch PowerShell Core via its exe Windows PowerShell then the window icon is still the old blue one in the window (but the taskbar icon is the new black one of PR #4848). This also affect the proposed context menu in issue #5012.
EDIT: I believe this is an issue with the exe itself because when double clicking on the exe `C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0-beta.7\powershell.exe` itself the new icon does not get applied either.

Steps to reproduce
------------------
Either double click on `C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0-beta.7\powershell.exe` or execute in Windows PowerShell:
`Start-Process "C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0-beta.7\powershell.exe"`

Expected behavior
-----------------

The icon in the window and taskbar should both be the new black ones.

Actual behavior
---------------

The icon in the window is the old blue icon but the taskbar icon is the new black one.

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-beta.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-beta.7-84-gee902a649e0b803b3db4619f7eeeadea5e60d0e6
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.15063
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0


```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: The icon is really only applying to the shortcut as the .exe itself doesn't have the icon embedded in its resources.  Proper fix is to add the icon the the resources of the exe, but that's not currently a priority.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: It seems dotnet/cli don't still support embedding custom icon in exe. 😕 https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/3267

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov we can use something like this: https://github.com/electron/rcedit

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: @iSazonov I don't understand how this can be an issue with the dotnet cli because my thinking is that the old blue PowerShell icon must come from somewhere. Or is this a red herring because PowerShell Core is somehow linked to Windows PowerShell?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @bergmeister I think the OS is doing something there to show the blue icon from Windows powershell.exe

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: Hmm, yes probably. I just found that this issue seems to be a duplicate of #2883

comments.author: bergmeister
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT  I manually tried `.\rcedit-x64.exe "path-to-powershell.exe" --set-icon "path-to-black-icon"` and although it changes the icon that is displayed in explorer.exe, it did not change the icon of the window when launching `PowerShell`. However when pointing `rcedit` to a HelloWorld .Net Core 2.0 console app exe, it worked (i.e. the icon also got applied to the Window icon). This suggest to me that somewhere in the Windows OS there is some registry key that overrides the icon for `powershell.exe`. Maybe this issue is a case for a rename to `psh.exe`? (JK)

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
Yes, think is a dupe of #2883

Agree that it's quite possible that the icon is associated to the powershell.exe process.

title: When starting PowerShell via its exe the new black icon is not applied in the Window (but in the taskbar)
